Zn–Al mixed oxides with different acidic and basic natures were synthesized under different pH (8.0–9.5) conditions and applied to the amination of methanol (MeOH). The physical and chemical properties of the samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as well as temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) with different probe molecules, such as NH3, CO2, iso-propanol (IPA), and MeOH. The conversion of MeOH and selectivity to acetonitrile (ACN) increased as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased to 9.5. The activity of the catalysts was in good accordance with the desorption temperatures of propylene in IPA-TPD and dimethyl ether in MeOH-TPD, while their selectivity to ACN was well correlated with the proportion of the weak base sites on the surface of the catalyst. Particularly, the changes in the acidity and basicity of the catalysts with the synthesis pH were mainly influenced by the degree of disorder of the ZnAl2O4 spinel structure. During the amination of MeOH, the catalytic activity, product selectivity, and deactivation behavior of the catalysts were affected by the reaction parameters. The Zn–Al mixed oxide catalyst was readily regenerated by via simple calcination, which removed the carbonitride and coke that were formed during the reaction. Graphical Abstract The conversion of methanol and selectivity to ACN in methanol amination were affected by the pH changes of the synthetic mixture of Zn-Al mixed oxide. ga1 Keywords ZnAl2O4 Amination Methanol Acetonitrile Acidity Basicity 1 Introduction Acetonitrile (ACN), a chemical compound, is widely used as a solvent (in butadiene extraction), a starting material (in acetophenone production), and a chemical intermediate (in pesticide production) [1]. The production of ACN from abundant resources, such as alcohols and ammonia (NH3), is an attractive alternative to the conventional Standard Oil of Ohio Company (SOHIO) process [2]. ACN is generally obtained as a by-product during the production of acrylonitrile via the ammoxidation of propylene with NH3 and air [3]. Thus, the development of on-purpose technologies, such as the ammoxidation of ethane and ethanol; the (reductive) amination of ethanol; and the direct conversions of CO, H2, and NH3 into ACN, for producing ACN has been studied to mitigate the dependency of its supply on the SOHIO process [4–9]. Among the various carbon resources for synthesizing ACN, methanol (MeOH) represents the most abundant feedstock because of the development of shale gas. However, the studies on the catalytic synthesis of ACN by MeOH amination has not been reported in the literature. As reported by Wang et al., the amination of MeOH with NH3 involves a multistep reaction comprising the dehydrogenation of MeOH into formaldehyde over metallic or basic centers, as well as the dehydration and amination of formaldehyde into methylene imine over acidic centers ( Scheme 1) [10]. Thereafter, methylamine or the nitrile compounds were formed by the hydrogenation or dehydrogenation of methylene imine, respectively, in the subsequent step. Thus, the utilization of multifunctional catalysts exhibiting acidic and basic/metallic functions is crucial to achieve the high conversion and selectivity of the desired product. Furthermore, the partial pressure of H2 during the reaction accounts for another critical factor that could determine the final products, such as nitrile and methylamine. Additionally, numerous reviews have been published on the catalytic roles of the acid–base sites [11–13]. Setoyama reported that acid–base bifunctional catalysts are categorized into two: a type in which they interact simultaneously with the substrate, and a type in which they interact successively with it [14]. The simultaneous interaction types are further divided into two: one involving a concerted mechanism in which the acid and base sites interact simultaneously with a single substrate by pulling and pushing the electron pairs, respectively, and one involving a go-together mechanism in which the acid and base sites interact simultaneously with two different substrates, but independently. On the other hand, catalytic reactions by successive acid–base interactions involve the generation of an intermediate, which subsequently interacts successively with the other type of catalytic site to form another species, over a certain reaction site. Therefore, the design of bifunctional catalysts by appropriately selecting the metal components is key to control their acidity and basicity, as well as their catalytic activity and product selectivity. Solid acid–base catalysts have been investigated for different applications because a catalyst design integrating the aforementioned properties can ensure higher conversion, selectivity, and stability compared with those of monofunctional catalysts [15]. Alumina is most widely used in industries as an acid catalyst and support; its acidic and basic properties can be modified by the additive type (metal or metal oxide) and the amount [16,17]. Al2O3-based mixed metal oxide catalysts exhibit interdispersed oxides with strong base sites, high surface areas, as well as form defect sites due to the substitution of Al3+ into the M2+ lattice [18]. Nguyen-Phu et al. reported the acidic and basic properties of a Zn–Al mixed oxide catalyst based on the formation of a disordered ZnAl2O4 spinel structure [19]. The degree of disorder of ZnAl2O4 could be defined by the inversion parameter, which is the proportion of Al3+ that occupied the tetrahedral sites of the catalysts, as measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Regarding the ZnAl2O4 spinel structure, the surface acidity and basicity of the catalysts increased proportionally with the increase in the inversion parameter. Therefore, the Zn–Al mixed oxide catalyst with control of the inversion parameter has the potential to show good activity in many acid–base catalysis. In this study, the amination of MeOH for the on-purpose production of ACN was investigated over Zn–Al mixed oxide catalysts that were synthesized under different pH conditions (8.0–9.5). The catalytic conversion and selectivity of the Zn–Al mixed oxides were correlated with the acid–base characteristics of the catalysts by the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of isopropanol and MeOH (IPA-TPD and MeOH-TPD, respectively). Additionally, the influences of the reaction parameters, such as the NH3/MeOH molar ratio and reaction temperature, on the catalytic performance were investigated. Based on the overall results of this study, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed for the amination of MeOH into ACN. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts The Zn–Al mixed oxide catalysts were synthesized by a coprecipitation method in the pH range of 8.0–9.5. Briefly, 0.047 and 0.094 mol of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Al(NO3)2⋅9H2O, respectively, were dissolved in 300 mL of deionized (DI) water, and a 14.7 M NH4OH solution was added dropwise under vigorous stirring at room temperature until the desired pH (8.0–9.5) was obtained. The suspension was aged for 24 h at room temperature, after which the solid products were recovered by filtration with 4 L of DI water and dried for 24 h at 100 °C. Thereafter, the samples were calcined in air flow for 4 h at 500 °C (1000 cm3 min−1). The resulting Zn–Al mixed oxides were denoted as ZA-x, where x represents the pH of the synthetic condition. Additionally, Al2O3 and ZnO were synthesized at pH 9.5 with Al and Zn nitrate solutions, respectively, following identical procedures to those of Zn–Al mixed oxide catalysts. 2.2 Characterizations of the catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on a D8 Discover (Bruker AXS). The scans were obtained in the 2θ range of 10–80° utilizing Cu Kα radiation (40 kV and 40 mA). The phase compositions of the Zn–Al mixed oxide were determined by the EVA search/match program combined with the JCPDS database. The surface areas and total pore volumes of the catalysts were determined from the N2 sorption experiments at −198 °C using an ASAP 2020 gas adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics). All the samples were pretreated in a vacuum for 4 h at 200 °C. The surface area of the catalyst was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method from the resulting adsorption isotherms in the range of P/P0 = 0.05–0.3, and the total pore volume was determined at P/P0 = 0.995. Further, the compositions of Zn and Al were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES; Optima 7300DV, PerkinElmer) after the complete digestion of each sample in a mixture of aqua regia and hydrofluoric acid (HF). NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD experiments were conducted with quadrupole mass spectrometry (QMS; QMS200, Balzers). Before the analysis, 0.1 g of the catalyst was pretreated for 1 h at 300 °C in an Ar flow (30 cm3 min–1). Thereafter, the samples were treated in flowing 5% NH3/Ar (30 cm3 min–1) or pure CO2 (30 cm3 min–1) for 0.5 h at 150 °C. After the NH3 or CO2 treatment, the reactor was purged for 0.5 h in flowing pure Ar (30 cm3 min–1) for the desorption of the weakly adsorbed NH3 or CO2 on the surface of the catalyst and heated from room temperature to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The mass signals of ·NH (m/z = 15) and ·CO2 (m/z = 44) were detected by QMS during NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD, respectively. Similar to NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analyses, MeOH and IPA were utilized as the probe molecules for the TPD experiments. The analysis condition was almost similar to those of NH3-TPD, except the sample was treated with 5% MeOH/Ar (30 cm3 min–1) and 5% IPA/Ar (30 cm3 min–1) at room temperature in MeOH-TPD and IPA-TPD, respectively. The mass signals corresponding to the fragments of ·H2 (m/z = 2), ·CH3O (m/z = 30), and ·CH2OCH3 (m/z = 45) were analyzed by MeOH-TPD, while those of ·C3H5 (m/z = 41) and ·CH3CO (m/z = 43) were detected in IPA-TPD experiments. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was performed with 0.03 g of the catalysts. The samples were heated to 800 °C in 5% O2/Ar (30 cm3 min–1) without pretreatment, and the ·NO (m/z = 30) and ·CO2 (m/z = 44) fragments were analyzed by TPO. The XPS spectra of the samples were recorded on a PHI Quantrea II (Ulvac-PHI) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation. The XPS spectra were calibrated with the adventitious carbon and C ls binding energy (BE, 284.6 eV) as the standard. 2.3 Activity test Catalytic experiments were performed using a fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure. Typically, 0.1 g of the catalyst sample was loaded in a quartz reactor and routinely pretreated in pure N2 flow for 1 h at 500 °C. Afterward, the temperature of the reactor was adjusted to the desired reaction temperature (450–525 °C). An isothermal activity test was conducted with the target feed ratio (NH3/MeOH = 1–7) balanced with N2 and a total flow rate of 100 cm3 min−1. The reactants and products of the amination of MeOH were detected by an online gas chromatography (CP 3800, Varian) that was equipped with a CP-Volamine column (60 m length and 320 μm i.d.) and a flame ionization detector (FID), as well as a Carbosphere column (2 m length and 1/8″ o.d.) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (Table S1). The conversion of MeOH, the selectivity to each product, and the deactivation rate of the catalysts were defined, as follows: Conversion ( % ) = F MeOH reacted F MeOH fed × 100 % i product selectivity ( % ) = F i C i ∑ F i C i × 100 % Deactivation r a t e ( % ) = Initial c onv . of MeOH − Conv . at 12 h on stream Initial conv . of MeOH × 100 % where F MeOH and F i are the molar flow rates of MeOH and i the products, respectively, C i is the number of carbon atoms in the i component. Additionally, special care should be taken when dealing with highly toxic hydrogen cyanide (HCN), and proper plan such as caustic scrubbing should be prepared. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The crystalline phases of the ZA-x catalysts were investigated by XRD ( Fig. 1 and Table 1). The catalysts synthesized at pH 8.5 (ZA-8.50) exhibited an Al-rich nonstoichiometric spinel (Zn0.3Al0.7)Al1.7O4-like crystalline phase (JCPDS No. 77-0732), and the structure was changed to pure stoichiometric spinel ZnAl2O4 (JCPDS No. 05-0669) as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased. The main peaks from ZnO (JCPDS No. 36-1451) around 2θ = 36.2° were not observed for all catalysts, and this indicated the complete conversion of the Zn species into the Zn–Al spinel without the formation of amorphous ZnO due to the transformation of amorphous ZnO to crystalline ZnO could occur at around 400 °C [20]. Fig. 1b shows that the peaks of ZA-8.00 around 66° shifted to lower angles, agreeing with the expected expansion of the lattice when the pH of the synthetic mixture increased to 9.5. This result can be explained by the lattice parameters that were calculated from the XRD patterns of the ZA-x catalysts. Compared with the lattice parameter of the nonstoichiometric spinel, ZnAl2O4 (a = 0.8000 nm), and the stoichiometric one, ZnAl2O4 (a = 0.8085 nm), the calculated values increased from 0.8013 to 0.8079 nm as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased from 8.0 to 9.5 (Table 1). These results demonstrated that the pH condition can affect the crystalline phases of catalysts. Following the structural transformation of the ZA-x catalyst into a pure ZnAl2O4 spinel under high pH synthetic conditions, the BET surface areas and total pore volumes increased from 123 to 244 m2 g−1 and from 0.139 to 0.289 cm3 g−1, respectively, whereas the average pore diameter decreased from 6.0 to 3.7 nm as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased from 8.0 to 9.5 (Table 1). Additionally, the Zn/Al molar ratios of the ZA-x catalysts, as determined by ICP analysis, decreased from 0.47 to 0.23 as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased from 8.0 to 9.5 owing to the decrease in the Zn content at pH >8.5. This can be explained by the formation of highly soluble [Zn(NH3)4]2+ ions, which are easily washed out during the filtration with DI water, by the reaction of precipitated Zn(OH)2 and NH4OH at pH >8.5 [21–23]. In line with the results of XRD and ICP analyses, as Rajkumar et. al reported, stoichiometric ZnAl2O4 spinel structure was synthesized with the Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.29 [24]. Nadjafi et al. also reported nonstoichiometric spinel ZnxAlyO4 that was synthesized with the different Zn/Al molar ratio [25]. Especially, Zn0.42Al2.39O4 catalyst (the Zn/Al molar ratio = 0.18) showed single-phase nanocrystalline spinel structure with a lattice parameter of 0.8064 nm which was the similar value over ZA-9.00 (0.8066 nm). From the 27Al MAS NMR analysis, tetrahedral Al3+ (AlT) and octahedral Al3+ (AlO) were confirmed over Zn0.42Al2.39O4 catalysts with the inversion parameter of 0.20, while only AlO was observed over ZnAl2O4. Thus, we expected that ZnAl2O4 spinel structure could be formed with the value of Zn/Al molar ratio <0.5 and the crystalline structure could be affected by synthetic pH by changing the degree of disorder of ZA-x catalysts. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were performed to investigate the changes in the acidic and basic properties of ZA-x with the variation in the pH values. Figs. S1a and 2a shows that the NH3-TPD profiles of the Al2O3 and ZA-x catalysts were characterized by two desorption peaks at 241 and 373 °C, which corresponded to the desorption of NH3 from the moderate and strong acid sites, respectively. The peak area of the high-temperature desorption peak in Al2O3 significantly decreased as the pH increased owing to the addition of Zn; moreover, ZA-9.50 exhibited almost two times the acid amount (380 vs 203 μmol g−1) compared with ZA-8.50 (Table S2) [26]. Similarly, the CO2-TPD profiles of the ZA-x catalysts showed additional CO2 desorption peaks at 364 °C (Peak I) and 460 °C (Peak II); these peaks were assignable to the moderate and strong base sites, respectively, and were not observed for Al2O3 (Figs. S1b and 2b) [26]. Additionally, the CO2 desorption peak of weak base sites could be observed at <200 °C. However, when CO2 were treated over ZA-x catalysts at room temperature, the distinction between physisorbed CO2 and chemisorbed CO2 on weak base sites was difficult since the peak area at <300 °C was almost similar over all catalysts (not shown here). Therefore, the samples were treated with CO2 at 150 °C during CO2-TPD experiment. The total base amount of ZA-x catalysts decreased from 22 to 13 μmol g−1 as synthetic mixture of pH increased from 8.0 to 9.5 due to the decrease in Zn content (Table S2). In amination of methanol, dimethyl ether (CH3OCH3; DME) was mainly produced without the production of ACN and HCN over Al2O3 catalyst that showed only the peak at 200 °C (not shown here), while those were produced on ZA-x catalysts. These results indicate that dehydrogenation occurred over Al2O3 catalyst due to absence of base sites and the peak that was observed at 200 °C was physisorbed CO2 on surface (Fig. S1b). Thus, the small amount of moderate and strong base sites affects to the production of ACN and HCN although the total amount of base sites (13–22 μmol g−1) was much less than those of acid sites (203–380 μmol g−1). The peak ratio of the strong base sites decreased from 48% to 13% as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased from 8.0 to 9.5, while the amount of the moderate base remained largely unchanged and its peak ratio increased to 86%, indicating that the acidic and basic properties of ZA-x could be controlled by adjusting the pH of the synthetic mixture. IPA-TPD is another effective tool for determining the strengths of the acid and base sites in catalysts. It explores the peak temperature for the desorption of ·C3H5 (m/z = 41) and ·CH3CO (m/z = 43) fragments, representing the acid-catalyzed dehydration of IPA into propylene and the base/metal-catalyzed dehydrogenation of IPA into acetone, respectively [27]. Fig. 2c, d show the evolution of the mass signal that corresponded to the ·C3H5 (m/z = 41) and ·CH3CO (m/z = 43) fragments as a function of the temperature during IPA-TPD. The peak temperature of the desorption of ·C3H5 (m/z = 41) (T m/z = 41) decreased from 242 to 225 °C as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased from 8.0 to 9.5, indicating the enhancement of the acid strength of the catalysts ( Table 2). Regarding the desorption of ·CH3CO (m/z = 43), the peak was deconvoluted into two peaks centered around 197–212 °C and 222–245 °C, corresponding to strong and moderate basic sites, respectively (Fig. 2d). In line with T m/z = 41, all the peak temperatures of the desorption of ·CH3CO (m/z = 43), T m/z = 43, also shifted to a lower temperature region, and the relative portion of the strong basic sites, which were calculated based on the peak areas of Peaks I and II, were reduced from 47% to 9% (Table 2). Additionally, during IPA-TPD, the peak areas of the peaks of the ·C3H5 and ·CH3CO fragments demonstrated a similar trend to those observed during NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. These results indicated that the acidity and basicity of the catalysts increased with the increasing synthetic pH values. The changes in the acidity and basicity might be related to the inversion parameter, as mentioned in the Introduction section; thus, the detailed reason for these changes would be discussed subsequently in the XPS results. The changes in the number of acidic or basic sites corresponding to the peak area in the TPD analysis can be explained by the change in the Zn content, as determined by the ICP analysis of ZA-x (Table 1). The decrease in the Zn content of the synthetic mixture at pH >8.5 induced the formation of [Zn(NH3)4]2+, which could be easily removed during filtration. Therefore, the changes in the peak area, as observed in the TPD analysis, clearly proved the decrease and increase in the numbers of basic sites (that were mainly formed by Zn) and acid sites (owing to the increase in the Al content), respectively. MeOH-TPD experiments were conducted to elucidate the adsorption and desorption behaviors of MeOH, which was used as a reactant in the amination reaction over ZnO, Al2O3, and ZA-x catalysts. During MeOH-TPD, different fragments were detected by the following reaction pathways: 2CH3OH → CH3OCH3 (m/z = 45) + H2O (m/z = 18) at the acid sites [28,29] and CH3OH → HCHO (m/z = 29) + H2 (m/z = 2) and ·CH3O → CO (m/z = 29) + 3/2 H2 (m/z = 2) at the base sites and the decompositions of the MeOH/HCHO/formate group into H2, CH4 (m/z = 15), CO (m/z = 28), and CO2 (m/z = 44) [30–32]. The results of the MeOH-TPD experiment over the Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. S2a) revealed that DME (m/z = 45) was mainly produced at ~194 °C by the dehydration of MeOH at the acid sites; the peaks of the ·H2 (m/z = 2), ·CH4 (m/z = 15), and ·CO (m/z = 28) fragments were detected by the decomposition of MeOH or DME (300–500 °C). The results of the MeOH-TPD experiment over the ZnO catalyst (Fig. S2b) revealed that the peak of HCHO (m/z = 29, ·CHO), which was produced by the dehydrogenation of MeOH at the base sites, was confirmed at 236 °C. The H2, CO, and CO2 molecules, which were formed by the decomposition of HCHO or the formate group, were confirmed in a lower temperature range (250–450 °C) compared with when the Al2O3 catalyst was employed without the formation of CH4. Fig. 3a shows that the evolution of the ·CH2OCH3 fragment (m/z = 45) on ZA-x as a function of the desorption temperature exhibited three peaks: Peaks I and II with different strengths (from the dehydration of MeOH at the acid sites) and Peak III (from the desorption of DME that was strongly adsorbed onto the surface of the catalyst) [33,34]. With the increasing pH of the synthetic mixture, the peak temperatures of fragment ·CH2OCH3 (m/z = 45) desorption (T m/z = 45) of Peaks I and II decreased from 238 to 225 °C and from 275 to 265 °C, respectively (Table 2). The Peak I portion that corresponded to the strong acid sites increased with the increasing total peak area. The desorption behavior of the ·H2 (m/z = 2) fragment is shown in Fig. 3b. The peaks of the ·H2 (m/z = 2) fragment were divided into four: Peaks I (210–340 °C) and II (250–350 °C), which were assigned to the dehydrogenation reactions of MeOH and methoxy at different base sites, respectively, and Peaks III (300–400 °C) and IV (340–430 °C) from the decomposition of the formate group [28,30–32]. Similar to the fragment of ·CH2OCH3 (m/z = 45), the peak temperature of the ·H2 fragment desorption (T m/z = 2) of Peak I shifted to a lower temperature when the synthetic pH increased (Table 2). However, T m/z = 2 of Peak II decreased from 308 to 305 °C (pH <9.0) and from 345 to 343 °C (pH ≥9.0) in the different synthetic pH ranges. The percentage of Peak I decreased from 47% to 7%, while that of Peak II increased to 93%. Additionally, the summation of Peaks I and II of the ·H2 fragment (m/z = 2) increased, although the total peak area of Peaks III and IV decreased with the increasing synthetic pH of the mixture (data not shown). Peaks III and IV shifted to a higher temperature because of the enhanced interactions between the surface and adsorbate over ZA-x that was synthesized at increased pH [35]. These results correlated with those of IPA-TPD such that the acidity and basicity of ZA-x increased with the increasing synthetic pH of the mixture. However, the increase in T m/z = 2 from 305 (over ZA-8.75) to 345 °C (over ZA-9.00) was caused by the stronger adsorption strength of the ZnAl2O4 spinel than those of the Al-rich nonstoichiometric Zn–Al spinel. Dissimilar to the decrease in the total peak area of the ·CH3CO (m/z = 43) fragment owing to the decrease in the Zn content during IPA-TPD, the total peak area of the ·H2 (m/z = 2) fragment for MeOH-TPD increased because of the formation of the methoxy groups, which increased the surface of the catalysts according to the increase in the oxygen defects, such as the lattice oxygen [30]. Additionally, except for the fragments, which exhibited the acidic and basic properties, in MeOH-TPD, new peaks of m/z = 30 (·CH2O) were observed on the ZA-x catalysts above 400 °C; they were not observed when Al2O3 and ZnO were employed (Figs. 3c and S2). Particularly, the area of the peak around 650 °C decreased sharply over the ZA-9.00 and ZA-9.50 catalysts, although these catalysts showed higher SBET values than those of catalysts that were synthesized at synthetic pH ≤8.5. These results indicated that new adsorption sites, which did not exist on the ZnO and Al2O3 catalysts, were formed on the ZA-x catalyst, for the adsorption of MeOH or methoxy owing to the formation of different crystalline phases, such as the Al-rich nonstoichiometric Zn–Al spinel and the stoichiometric ZnAl2O4 spinel. The normal spinel structure of ZnAl2O4 contains Zn2+ and Al3+ at the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of a cubic close-packed crystal, respectively. The partially inverse spinel structure is a disordered ZnAl2O4 structure in which some Al3+ and Zn2+ cations occupy the tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively [19,36]. The degree of disorder can be calculated by XPS from an inverse parameter that is defined as a portion of the tetrahedrally coordinated Al3+ or octahedrally coordinated Zn2+, respectively [37,38]. The XPS spectra of Zn 2p3/2, Al 2p, O 1s, and Zn LMM were obtained to elucidate the structural changes in ZnAl2O4 depending on the pH of synthetic mixture ( Fig. 4 and Table 3). Normally, the BE of cation at octahedral sites showed the higher value than that of cation at tetrahedral sites due to the increase in electronegativity of the surrounding by the increase in the number of oxygen atom [39]. Each Zn 2p3/2 peak in the ranges of 1021.1–1022.0 eV and 1023.4–1023.7 eV was assigned to tetrahedrally coordinated Zn2+ (ZnT) and octahedrally coordinated Zn2+ (ZnO), respectively [38]. The Al 2p peak was deconvoluted into two peaks: the peak at the higher BE (74.1–75.0 eV) was assigned to the AlO, and that at the lower BE (73.4–74.6 eV) was assigned to the AlT [40]. Conversely, the peak ratios of ZnO and AlT showed the opposite trend, while the inversion parameter, which was calculated from the deconvoluted peak area in the Zn 2p3/2 and Al 2p regions, correlated with similar values. The O 1s XPS spectrum was deconvoluted into three peaks: the first peak at 531.2 ± 0.1 eV, which corresponded to the lattice oxygen in ZnAl2O4 (OZA); the peak at 532.8 eV, which was assigned to the oxygen-deficient regions or the oxygen vacancy (Ov); and the peak at 534.1 eV, which was assigned to the absorbed oxygen species, such as the hydroxyl group, on the surface of the catalyst (Oa). The Ov portion increased when the pH of the synthetic mixture was changed from 8.0 to 9.5, while the OZA portion decreased under the same condition. Similar to the inversion parameter for the ZnAl2O4 spinel structure, Ov could be generated to balance the positive charge of the cations in the octahedral site after the substitution of Zn2+ in the tetrahedral site with Al3+ in the octahedral site [41]. Therefore, the increase in the Ov portion correlated with the increasing or decreasing tendency of ZnO or AlT, respectively. The two peaks, which were observed in the Zn LMM region, corresponded to the interstitial Zn (Zni, 495.7 ± 0.1 eV) and Zn in ZnAl2O4 (ZnZA, 498.9–499.2 eV) [42,43]. The ZA-8.00 catalyst exhibited the highest Zni portion, which decreased gradually as the synthetic pH of the mixture increased to 9.5. These results, as well as the XRD and N2 sorption results (Fig. 1 and Table 1), indicated that the Al-rich nonstoichiometric spinel crystalline phase, which was observed on the catalyst synthesized at pH ≤8.75, was mainly due to the imbalance in the Zn/Al ratio owing to the high proportion of the interstitial Zn. The change in the crystalline phase from Al-rich nonstoichiometric spinel into the pure stoichiometric ZnAl2O4 spinel, as well as the increase in SBET with the increasing pH, were caused by an increase in the inversion parameter of the ZnAl2O4 spinel. Additionally, the changes in the acidic and basic properties, as revealed by TPD (Figs. 2 and 3), can be explained by the following reasons with regards to the XPS results: the formation of quasi-trihedral Al, which exhibited a low-energy acceptor orbital, on the surface of ZnAl2O4, and an increase in the surface Ov due to an increase in the surface −OH group [44,45]. Detailedly, the increases in the acidity, as well as the number of acid sites, were caused by the formation of quasi-trihedral Al, which exhibited high electronegativity; moreover, the increase in the basicity, as well as the decrease in the number of basic sites, was related to the formation of the surface −OH groups and a decrease in Zn mol%, respectively. As explained, the increases in the acidity and basicity (TPD analysis) correlated well with the increases in the inversion parameter and Oa percentage, as calculated from the deconvoluted peak area in the XPS results. Thus, the formation of a disordered structure, which depending on the pH condition, on the ZnAl2O4 surface affected the physicochemical properties of ZA-x. 3.2 Amination of MeOH over ZA-x The catalytic performances of the ZA-x catalysts were compared in the amination of MeOH. Scheme 2 shows the possible reaction pathway based on the products that were detected during the amination of MeOH over ZA-x. Further, Fig. S3 and Table 4 showed that DME and the C1 compounds (CH4 and CO), which were observed during MeOH-TPD, were produced, although CO2 and HCHO were not detected during the reaction. Further, the C2 compounds (C2H4, C2H6, and CH3CHO) and heavy products (acetamide and the C4 compounds), as well as amine compounds, such as monomethylamine (MMA), dimethylamine (DMA), and trimethylamine (TMA), were confirmed. Particularly, the amine selectivity employing all the catalysts decreased in the following order: MMA >> DMA > TMA. The distributions of the amines on the ZA-x catalysts differed from the thermodynamic equilibrium in which TMA, rather than MMA and DMA, was the major product [46]. It has been reported that small-pore zeolites could effectively increase the selectivity to MMA or DMA during MeOH amination [47–50]. However, since ZA-x exhibited the characteristics of mesoporous materials (N2 sorption analysis; Tables 1 and 4), the decrease in selectivity to DMA and TMA might have been caused by the production of HCN during the dehydrogenation of MMA. The catalytic activity test was conducted at 450 °C to investigate the effect of the synthesis pH on the ZA-x catalysts ( Figs. 5 and S3 and Table 4). As the pH increased to 9.5, the initial conversion and selectivity to ACN increased from 44% to 76% and from 23% to 58%, respectively. Contrarily, the highest selectivity to HCN was achieved by ZA-8.00, and the deactivation rate decreased from 53% to 9% with the increasing synthesis pH. These results could be related to the increase in the acidity, as well as the changes in the proportions of the different basic sites in IPA-TPD and MeOH-TPD analyses. Fig. 6 shows the correlation of the conversion and selectivity over ZA-x catalysts with their basic properties based on the changes in the synthetic pH, as analyzed by IPA-TPD and MeOH-TPD. The conversion of the ZA-x catalyst exhibited an inverse correlation with T m/z = 41 in IPA-TPD and T m/z = 45 in MeOH-TPD (Fig. 6a and Table 2). The selectivities to ACN and HCN correlated well with Peaks I and II portions of the ·CH3CO (m/z = 43) fragment in IPA-TPD, as well as the ·H2 (m/z = 2) fragment in MeOH-TPD. These results indicated that the conversion of MeOH was related to the acidity of the catalyst, and the selectivities to ACN and HCN were related to the number of weak and strong base sites, respectively. Thus, controlling the acidic and basic properties of the ZA-x catalyst was key to determining the yield of the nitrile compounds during MeOH amination. 3.3 Effects of the reaction parameters on MeOH amination MeOH amination was performed at different NH3/MeOH molar ratios (1–7) and reaction temperatures (450–525 °C) over ZA-9.50 to determine the optimal conditions for achieving the selective production of ACN. By increasing the molar ratio of NH3/MeOH from 1 to 7, the initial activity of ZA-9.50 decreased from 79% to 72%, and its selectivity to ACN decreased from 58% to 54% with a decrease in DME selectivity ( Fig. 7a and Table 5). Increasing the molar ratio of NH3/MeOH negatively affected the MeOH conversion of the catalysts and their selectivities to ACN. However, their deactivation rate was lowered to 5% after 12 h of reaction, indicating improved catalyst stability. Thus, the highest yield was obtained at NH3/MeOH = 5. The effect of the reaction temperature was investigated employing a fixed ratio of NH3/MeOH, and the highest ACN yield was achieved in 12 h (Fig. 7b and Table 5). By increasing the reaction temperature, the conversion and selectivity to ACN increased to 98% and 63%, respectively, and the deactivation rate reduced to 1.6%. These results indicated that the increased adsorption of NH3 onto the acid sites with the increasing partial pressure of NH3 decreased the catalytic activity by suppressing the production of DME from MeOH and increased the selectivity to HCN and the amines by increasing the production of MMA. The increase in the reaction temperature reduced the deactivation rate of the catalysts by removing the strongly adsorbed methoxy group from their surfaces, as observed in MeOH-TPD in the range of 400–550 °C (Fig. 3c); it also increased the selectivity to the nitrile compounds by increasing the dehydrogenations of MMA and DME. 3.4 Regeneration test and deactivation of the catalysts To confirm the regenerability of the ZA-9.50 catalyst in the amination of MeOH, the experiment was performed by repeating its regeneration in the air for 2 h at 500 °C after the activity test for 65 h at 525 °C ( Fig. 8a). The gradual deactivation of the catalytic performance of the catalyst from 98% to 95% was observed for 20 h, after which it sharply decreased to 76% within 45 h. However, 98% of its initial conversion (before regeneration) was recovered after the regeneration. Further, its selectivity to ACN increased gradually within the first 60 h (before regeneration), whereas it increased by ~3%, and decreased subsequently after regeneration. The same trend was observed after the second regeneration. To understand the cause of the catalyst deactivation during the amination of MeOH, TPO and XPS analyses were performed employing ZA-9.50 (Fresh) and ZA-xR-y h that was obtained during the regeneration test (x and y represent the number of regeneration and the time on stream, respectively) (Fig. 8b–d). Based on the results of the TPO analysis, the C and N species that were adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst after the reaction were mainly observed as ·CO2 (m/z = 44) and ·NO (m/z = 30), respectively (Fig. 8b). For the ZA-0R-4 h catalyst, the peak of the ·CO2 fragment appeared at 139 °C, and the peak of the ·NO fragment was detected at 139 and 366 °C. Conversely, the peak area increased on the ZA-2R-195 h catalyst, and new peaks that were not observed on the ZA-0R-4 h catalyst at 564 °C (·CO2), as well as 315 and 585 °C (·NO). The peaks of the C and N compounds could be classified according to the temperature region: the first peak at <200 °C was from the adsorbed reactant, the second peak at 200–500 °C was from the amorphous coke and surface carbonitride, and the third peak at >500 °C was from hard carbon or graphitic coke [51,52]. The results obtained from the XPS analysis that was performed to further elucidate the adsorbed C and N species indicated that the fresh catalyst displayed three peaks, which corresponded to C–C (284.6 eV), C–O (285.7–287.2 eV), and C=O (288.3–289.8 eV) from the adventitious carbon in the C 1s region; however, no peak relating to the N compounds was observed (Fig. 8c, d) [53–55]. Employing the ZA-xR-y h catalysts, new peaks were observed in the C 1s and N 1s regions (the peaks at 283.4 (C–H) and 285.7 eV (C–N) were associated with the strongly adsorbed carbon species and carbonitride, and the peak at 399.7 eV (C–N) was assigned to carbonitride). The N 1s spectra did not exhibit the N–H peak at 405.3 eV [56]. The percentages of C–N and C–O were 2% and 21% on the ZA-0R-4 h catalyst, and 16% and 14% on ZA-2R-195 h, respectively ( Table 6). In line with the C 1s spectra, the peak area of C–N in the N 1s spectrum increased as the reaction time increased. The results of the TPO and XPS experiments indicated that the relatively low deactivation at the initial stage of the reaction (0–20 h) was due to the formation of surface carbonitride or weakly adsorbed carbon species at the active site of the catalyst. The rapid deactivation after 20 h was due to the blockage of the active sites on the catalyst by the formation of bulk carbonitride and hard coke. 4 Conclusions In this study, the amination of MeOH was conducted toward achieving the selective production of ACN over ZA-x catalysts that were synthesized under different pH conditions. The catalysts, which were synthesized at pH <9.0 exhibited an Al-rich nonstoichiometric spinel crystalline phase, which was changed into the stoichiometric ZnAl2O4 spinel crystalline phase as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased to 9.5. The changes in the pH of the synthetic mixture affected the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. Particularly, the acidity and basicity of the catalysts increased with the increasing synthetic pH of the mixture from 8.0 to 9.5 owing to the increase in the formation of a disordered spinel structure on the surface of ZA-x. For the amination of MeOH, the ZA-9.50 catalyst showed the highest conversion and selectivity to ACN; it also exhibited the lowest deactivation rate compared with the others. The catalytic activity of the catalysts correlated well with T m/z = 41 and T m/z = 45 in IPA-TPD and MeOH-TPD, respectively, and the selectivity to nitrile compounds was related to the ratios of the weak and strong base sites, as confirmed by the fragments of ·CH3CO and ·H2 in IPA-TPD and MeOH-TPD, respectively. Additionally, the optimal condition for achieving the selective production of ACN was investigated by changing the molar ratio of NH3/MeOH, as well as the reaction temperature. The results of the TPO and XPS analyses of the catalysts that were obtained at a different time on stream during the regeneration test revealed that the rapid deactivation of the ZA-9.50 catalyst after 20 h of MeOH amination was caused by the formation of hard coke and bulk carbonitride; the catalyst was easily regenerated after calcination. These results confirmed that the synthetic changes in the pH of the ZA-x catalysts affected their conversion and selectivity toward ACN by varying their acidity and basicity. Particularly, an increase in the acidity and the proportion of weak base sites are key to the selective production of ACN. coredata.dc:description: Zn–Al mixed oxides with different acidic and basic natures were synthesized under different pH (8.0–9.5) conditions and applied to the amination of methanol (MeOH). The physical and chemical properties of the samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as well as temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) with different probe molecules, such as NH3, CO2, iso-propanol (IPA), and MeOH. The conversion of MeOH and selectivity to acetonitrile (ACN) increased as the pH of the synthetic mixture increased to 9.5. The activity of the catalysts was in good accordance with the desorption temperatures of propylene in IPA-TPD and dimethyl ether in MeOH-TPD, while their selectivity to ACN was well correlated with the proportion of the weak base sites on the surface of the catalyst. Particularly, the changes in the acidity and basicity of the catalysts with the synthesis pH were mainly influenced by the degree of disorder of the ZnAl2O4 spinel structure. During the amination of MeOH, the catalytic activity, product selectivity, and deactivation behavior of the catalysts were affected by the reaction parameters. The Zn–Al mixed oxide catalyst was readily regenerated by via simple calcination, which removed the carbonitride and coke that were formed during the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Amination of methanol for selective production of acetonitrile over Zn-Al mixed oxide catalysts synthesized at different pH
